Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Synthetic Control of Metabolism by Dynamic Metabolons

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project addresses a challenging problem in metabolic engineering, namely the channelling of chemical reactions in the cell into metabolic pathways in an efficient and dynamically controlled manner, but without affecting cellular growth. The two collaborators offer complementary expertise in the analysis of metabolic flux and protein engineering in order to pursue a highly innovative design concept to achieve this goal. The students trained on this project will be exposed to multi-disciplinary training in the context of research that is anticipated to significantly advance biomanufacturing capabilities.

The goal is to develop synthetic dynamic metabolons that will allow carbon flux to be redirected as desired. The end result will be the ability to provide dynamic optimization of microbial metabolism for optimal product formation. This will be achieved by dynamic shifts between the assembly and disassembly of synthetic metabolons in order to modulate the overall output function. Specifically, successive metabolic enzymes will be coupled onto Pumilio (PUF) modules, which are also capable of binding specific riboswitches. These riboswitches are designed to respond to specific metabolic or synthetic signals. Feasibility will be demonstrated by designing two multi-enzyme dynamic metabolons, one that converts methanol into hexulose-6-phosphate, which is a valuable precursor for chemical and fuel production. The second metabolon includes enzymes that convert acetyl-CoA into mevalonate. The ultimate goal is to combine the knowledge gained toward the design of dynamic metabolons for enhanced fatty acid synthesis.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The ability to optimize pathway flux is one of the most important factors toward maximizing product titers. The traditional approaches largely focused on the overexpression of rate-limiting enzymes, competing pathway deletion, and resource management. However, most of these approaches are static in nature and do not provide dynamic regulation of pathway fluxes based on substrate, precursor, and product availability. Although many genetic circuit designs have been implemented to provide dynamic control of gene expression and pathway fluxes, these dynamic strategies usually provide only excellent “up-regulation” control but down regulation is much slower as it requires the degradation of the associated regulatory components. Here, we developed a new strategies that provide faster on-and-off control based on enzyme proximity control inspired by natural dynamic metabolons. This design is based on the dynamic assembly and disassembly of synthetic metabolons in order modulate the overall output function.

Although synthetic scaffolds based on protein and DNA have been reported, modulating protein assembly is a very challenging task due to a lack of dynamic assembly. In contrast, RNA is inherently dynamic in nature and can be modulated easily based on toehold-mediated strand displacement. We chose to use the Cas6 endonuclease family that is responsible for crRNA processing in Type I and Type III CRISPR systems to generate protein-RNA complexes.  Cas6 binds and cleaves within each repeat sequence of the precursor crRNA (pre-crRNA) transcript to generate a library of different crRNAs containing a unique flanking DNA-targeting spacer sequence. A key hallmark of single-turnover Cas6 proteins is the high affinity (~50 pM) and specificity with which they bind and process RNA targets. The repeating stable stem-loop structures on the pre-crRNA transcript serve as a Cas6 handle to initiate the cleavage by hydrolyzing a single phosphodiester bond at the 3’ end of the stem-loop structure. By taking advantage of the stem-loop specificity, parallel binding and cleavage of a long RNA transcript is possible by employing a set of orthogonal Cas6 enzymes from different species.

Two orthogonal Cas6 proteins, Csy4 from Pseudomonas aeruginosa strain UCBPP-PA14, and the Cse3 from E. coli, were selected based on their specific recognition of a unique hairpin for pM affinity binding. The feasibility of using Csy4 to organize proteins by RNA-guided assembly was first demonstrated using conditional split protein complementation, for which two protein fragments are conditionally reassembled when fused to two interacting Csy4 proteins. The recently reported split nanoluciferase (NLuc) is ideally suited for this assay as the two split fragments, called LgBiT (18 kDa) and SmBiT (1.3 kDa and 11 amino acid), are very small and can be easily inserted without affecting the partner protein function. Two fusion proteins, Csy4-LgBiT and Cse3-SmBiT, were created to enable the RNA-guided assembly of Cas6-appended LgBiT and SmBiT.

When the two fusion proteins were expressed without any gRNA guides, the activity remained minimal. In contrast, when both fusion proteins were expressed in conjunction with the appropriate gRNA strand, there is a 200-fold increase in luminescence when compared to the two proteins on their own. The large increase in luminescence indicated that scaffold assembly requires all of the components of the system to be present in order to properly assemble. More importantly, this result also highlights the ability of the two Cas6 proteins to bind and cleaves the single RNA transcript into two separate RNA guides for sequence-specific hybridization

The ability to trigger the disassembly of split Nluc by toehold-mediated strand displacement was further demonstrated by co-expressing either a correct trigger or a scramble trigger for displacement. For the three different designs, only correct trigger can displace the assembly, while the scramble trigger is incapable of displacement. The level of residual luminescence after displacement is on par with that of a RNA guide not capable of assembling the split NLuc, highlighting the effectiveness of the strand displacement in disassembling the RNA-guided hybridization to a level similar to the scramble assembly sequence.   Moving forward this is an important result because it underscores that we have conditional disassembly of the scaffold driven by the presence of small native or synthetic RNAs
